Award.AwardTitle: The Privilege of Student, Experiential Learning, Engineering Competition Teams (SELECT)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This STEP Type 2 project is a study that identifies and examines the factors that contribute to differential levels of student participation in student engineering competitions. Generally, engineering faculty and industry representatives have positive views towards Student, Experiential Learning, Engineering Competition Teams (SELECT) that are sponsored by professional engineering societies. These national competitions offer students the opportunity to develop technical engineering skills, teamwork skills, and other non-technical professional skills through designing and building projects and testing their performance. For example, professional organizations sponsor competitions that require students to solve problems associated with building vehicles for challenging terrains or building devices out of specified materials that can perform specific tasks. These competitions are designed to foster innovative thinking, the application of engineering principles, and professional skills through solving open-ended, constrained problems. While the numbers of students participating in these types of competitions have increased over the years, participation by students from traditionally underrepresented groups remains disproportionately low when compared to the demographics of students enrolled in engineering programs. This study identifies and examines the underlying beliefs, assumptions, policies, and practices contributing to cultures of inclusion and/or exclusion in these team competitions. The study is guided by a theoretical framework that suggests that underlying social motivations (e.g., power, ideology, maintenance of the status quo) and mechanisms (e.g., political, economic, language) shape social relationships in institutions. The mixed-qualitative study investigates the following question, What factors contribute to cultures of inclusion or exclusion within Student, Experiential Learning, Engineering Competition Teams? The research team hypothesizes that the most significant factors contributing to team cultures of inclusion or exclusion fall into several general categories: extrinsic influences, group dynamics, and individual attributes, motivators, and agency.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Student Experiential Learning Engineering Competition Teams (SELECT) are an important part of engineering education. SELECT typically design, build, and compete with engineered objects, such as race cars, concrete canoes, and autonomously controlled aircraft. Teams typically have a faculty advisor, a substantial budget, and space to work. Most SELECT have twenty students or less. Many engineering colleges highlight these teams on their websites, in recruiting prospective students, and in reaching potential donors.

The Research Institute for STEM Education (RISE) focused its attention on SELECT when a highly qualified female prospective student visiting a building dedicated to hands-on engineering projects asked “Are girls allowed to be on the team?” We discovered that the teams at our institution and nationally consisted almost exclusively of white men.  This discovery raised the question of whether women and people of color are being intentionally or unintentionally excluded from SELECT. The National Science Foundation funded this study to determine the reasons for this imbalance and made it possible for us to develop recommendations to open SELECT to everyone.

Our study used many sources of information about SELECT. We individually interviewed student SELECT members and faculty advisors from a variety of institutions. We surveyed students from competition teams across the country. We spoke to corporate recruiters about how they view SELECT participation. The findings listed below are based on the analysis of this data.

Our research revealed a number of ways that SELECT maintain an organizational culture that excludes women and persons of color. Teams recruited new members from their existing circle of friends, which tend to be single gender/race/ethnicity and major. Hence groups of white men tend to recruit more white men. Many SELECT had a culture of zealous team commitment to the exclusion of academic work, social or family life, and employment. This time requirement resulted in exclusion of students who prioritize any of those important life responsibilities.

Team members told us that they sought new team members that fit and had specific engineering or construction skills. The concept of fit is problematic because many engineering students lack the social understanding to recognize that fit can be biased against those who are perceived to be different. Requiring skills as a prerequisite to team membership is problematic because SELECT are supposed to be learning experiences. We also found that women who had these skills were not as able to find acceptance in the team as some men who lacked any skills.

Furthermore, teams generally had little awareness of the benefits of diversity nor faced any requirements to ensure broad participation. Team members told us that women were not excluded from team participation: Women simply weren’t interested. However, we found women who were interested but unable to break into the fraternity-like team culture. The excluding attitudes and behaviors of team members is compounded by the history of the engineering objects, of which many historically have excluded women and persons of color. For example, formula one racing has roots as the playground for European aristocracy. Women who did find a place on a team were often assigned the non-technical work, such as required presentations.

The benefits that are presumed to occur from SELECT participation are overstated. Many teams had poor leadership and unsuccessful management and no training in those areas. In addition, some teams were doing very little engineering. For example, tests and spreadsheets from previous years were reused and intuition sometimes replaced engineering. While some companies appear to preferentially recruit SELECT members, we were unable to document the type of industry-wide preference of SELECT members over other engineering graduates that is sometimes used to encourage students to join SELECT.

The first impact of our research is to draw national attention to the stark lack of diversity in SELECT, and the resulting unfairness of devoting so many educational resources to small groups of students. We have made many invisible barriers to participation in SELECT visible. Our research led to a broad set of recommendations for how SELECT members should be trained, recruited, and integrated into teams. We recommended changes to the competitions to increase the diversity of students who can participate. We developed recommendations for institutions that host SELECT, SELECT faculty advisors, SELECT student team leaders, SELECT team members, and corporate sponsors of SELECT. The implementation of these recommendations should result in a re-examination of the role of SELECT in engineering education, and give institutions a map to make SELECT truly available to everyone.
